awd_titl_txt: DMREF: Analysis and Optimization of Polymer Networks for Emerging Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
Polymers are ubiquitous in our world.  Many applications require the use of materials with lightweight, but high mechanical strength.  For this purpose, polymer networks are made by interconnecting the individual polymer fibers.  To enable the fabrication of network materials with fewer defects and superior properties, Professors Johnson and Olsen of Massachusetts Institute of Technology seek to develop experimental and theoretical strategies for preparing new polymer networks and understanding their structures at the molecular level.  The project aims to gain important fundamental knowledge for guiding the design of next-generation materials for biomedical applications, light harvesting, and membrane technology.  The broader impacts of the project involve interdisciplinary research training of graduate and undergraduate students through a strong collaboration between experiment and theory. The research team also develops hands-on teaching modules on polymer gels for middle school students.

There are three complementary research components in this project that are co-funded by the NSF Division of Chemistry and the Division of Materials Research.  The first part aims to develop experimental techniques for quantitative analysis of defects in polymer networks.  The second part seeks to understand the relationship between network topology and monomer feed rate and to develop new theoretical and computational methods to predict how network topology relates to processing conditions. The final aim focuses on the development of a new method for controlling network topology using light.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The properties of polymer networks are defined by chemical composition, connectivity, and topology. Much of the classical knowledge related to polymer networks was built upon assumptions of networks with ideal structures that do not reflect real materials. For example, according to classical theories of rubber elasticity for non-entangled rubbery networks, the shear modulus of a rubbery network, Gʹ, depends linearly on the density of elastically active chains neff. The latter parameter is impossible to measure, however, in real materials because of invisible yet pervasive elastically defective topologies that reduce Gʹ and preclude a molecular-level understanding of polymer network structure-property relationships. Similarly, inconsistencies between real materials and ideal materials pervade classical theories for other key material properties such as tearing energy and swelling. A complete understanding of how to design and predict the properties of next-generation polymer materials is not possible without fully understanding how to measure and control network topology. This project addresses this critical knowledge gap, providing design principles for novel functional, sustainable polymer materials.

 

Intellectual Merit: This DMREF project resulted in at least 32 peer-reviewed publications that impacted the field?s understanding of polymer network structure and theory. For example, a new theory of elasticity?the ?Real Elastic Network Theory? (RENT)?was proposed, which quantitively accounts for the impact of loop topologies in real polymer networks. This theory was made possible by novel experimental methods that provided the first precise measurements of loop topologies in synthesized networks. Insights gained from these studies enabled the invention of fundamentally new classes of polymer networks, including supramolecular networks composed of precise metal?organic cage nanoparticle junctions linked together through polymers, and photoactive polymer networks that grow when exposed to sunlight and monomer feedstocks. Such materials have potential applications as green catalysts, switchable materials, and as host materials for selective separations. Moreover, this proposal led to a new strategy for deconstructing and recycling hydrocarbon thermosets, one of the most pernicious classes of perpetual plastics.  

 

Broader Impacts: This project gave critical training to several students and post-docs. The first post-doc involved in the project, Dr. Huaxing Zhou, developed the first methods for quantifying loops in polymer networks experimentally. Zhou trained multiple graduate students (Jenny Liu, Alexandra Cok, and Ken Kawamoto). A joint postdoctoral researcher in the PI?s groups, Dr. Mingjiang Zhong, led the RENT studies along with Kawamoto and Dr. Rui Wang. Zhong is now an Assistant Professor at Yale University (Chemical and Environmental Engineering), Kawamoto is a research scientist at 3M, and Wang is an Assistant Professor at UC Berkeley (Chemical Engineering). Dr. Julia Zhao was mentored by Zhong and received her PhD from MIT in 2020; she is now a research scientist at act.nano Inc. Ms. Chew Chai (MIT undergraduate) was mentored by Dr. Zhong during Spring 2015. Former PhD student Mr. Aleksandr V. Zhukhovitskiy led the polyMOC project; Aleksandr is now an Assistant Professor at UNC Chapel Hill (Chemistry). Dr. Yuwei Gu, a former graduate student, is currently a postdoc at Northwestern with Prof. Chad Mirkin. Jessica Lamb and Junpeng Wang, former postdocs on the project, are Assistant Professors at Minnesota (Chemistry) and Akron (Polymer Science), respectively. Former PhD student who led early simulation work on the project, Dr. Muzhou (Mitchell) Wang is now an Assistant Professor at Northwestern University (Chemical Engineering). Non-PI members of this project presented this work at multiple Gordon Research Conferences, ACS National meetings, and universities (e.g., University of Connecticut, University of Massachusetts Amherst, Northwestern, MIT Polymer Day seminar). The PI?s have hosted visiting researchers from Brazil, visiting students from around the world, and visiting Roxbury community college students, all of whom were involved in the project. The PIs have presented over 175 invited lectures on research related to the project at various universities, companies, and conferences. They have incorporated their analysis of loops in polymer networks into their MIT course curricula including in organic reaction mechanisms and polymer synthesis courses. The computational methods developed in this project are disseminated through a website, enabling researchers from around the world to adopt these methods for polymer network design.

 


Last Modified: 01/13/2022
Modified by: Jeremiah Johnson

Image
  • Working together synergistically, the teams of Johnson and Olsen introduced several breakthrough experimental, computational, and theoretical tools to the field of polymer networks.
    Johnson and Olsen
    Public Domain
    Jeremiah Johnson
